Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: New tools, lots of new perspectives and the ability to make a project relevant with minimal prior info
I learned useful tools like LCA and MFA. I also learned about industrial symbiosis and ways that can reduce the environmental impact of industries.

I learned about various tools to measure and evaluate material flows and resources. It was an introductory course, but did not go into any of the subjects enough to provide students with a deeper understanding of these issues.
Basic fluency of LCA and Industrial Ecology concepts.

I gained familiarity with the various methods and tools of industrial ecological analysis (LCA, MFA, etc.), the concepts of industrial symbiosis and metabolism, and the issues involved in defining material stocks and flows. I learned that recycling is not as straightforward as it might seem and that all materials contain embedded environmental costs that must be accounted for.

I learned about the broad range of tools and concepts in the industrial ecology field - from MFA to industrial symbiosis. I also learned about industrial ecology's applications in industry and policy.
I.S, Circular economy, MFA, LCA
I gained knowledge around some of the analytical techniques of industrial ecology. I would have liked greater focus on this area rather than have a survey of some more superfluous topics.
Not sure. I think I could have learned this from reading a few blog posts on the topic.
Learned about the tools and limits of industrial ecology.

This is a good introductory class for industrial ecology, which offers great insights about life-cycle analysis and valuable opportunities for students to work on real-world problems through the final project.

Introduction to industrial ecology concepts and examples, such as Life Cycle Analysis, Material Flow Analysis, etc. The course did not really cover how to apply these concepts (e.g. although we learned how to analyze a Life Cycle Analysis, we did not learn how to conduct one ourselves).
I was a bit underwhelmed with the course. Often it felt improvised and that was demotivating.
I was disappointed by the superficial coverage of topics and wish that it was taught at a higher level.
I thought I would come away with more tools and hands-on application. I expected to be more interested in Industrial Ecology at the end of the course.

In some ways the insights gained from the class aligned with my expectations, such as learning more about the need to address materials in our climate solutions. However, in other ways, the class did not meet my expectations. I expected more exposure to quantitative analysis, and the basic math we did was not what I had in mind coming into the class. I also expected to have the chance to more explicitly explore the data and information used in the examples given in lectures, but I realize that might be challenging without learning more specifically about the analytical tools.
Very well. I wanted a comprehensive introduction to the field and received just that.

I believe I got out of the course what I expected to, although I thought we would get some practice learning how to build a Sankey diagram or perform an LCA analysis on our own. Instead, we learned how to interpret those analyses. The course definitely stays within the bounds of an intro course intended to prepare students for future industrial ecology classes.
I thought it was going to be more focused on a specific organization, more than the worldwide context.
I was expecting industrial ecology to be more applicable to the real world. I found the field to be largely academic which is not as useful to me.

I thought I came to this school to learn Industrial Ecology, and I was very sad that this was how it was presented. The instructors didn't expect much from us and thus I stopped engaging and didn't expect much from the course.

Industrial ecology is less well developed than I expected. Finding the data is a large part of it. I didn't get quite as much on the ground experience with the tools, but the instruction in general was quite good and to expectation!
I believe this class offers more knowledge and skills than I expected. Also, the final project gives us a great opportunity to actually use these skills.
The class was much more theory-based than expected, with less discussion of practical applications of industrial ecology concepts than I had hoped.
The course could have been more cohesive in the order in which the lectures were arranged.
topics are incredibly interesting. But the class felt disorganized and the assignments irrelevant.

Having guest lecturers was a huge strength. However, weaknesses included a general lack of organization, poor TF staff (assignments didn't use proper grammar and changed assignment requirements shortly before the deadline), professors were not good at lecturing and teaching the course material, and the final assignment was poorly constructed (not being able to get data from clients and having only 6 weeks to complete the assignment resulted in a superficial end product).

Strengths: solid lineup of guest speakers. Robert Klee in particular provided a great (and highly engaging) example of how industrial ecology can be applied in professional practice.  
The majority of classes were dry and theoretical, and would benefit from pulling in case studies, policy memos, or other methods (eg. small group discussions) for engaging actively in the material. Term projects could have been a chance to do this, but started too late to be maximally meaningful.

The course provided a good overview of the challenges inherent in industrial ecology and the role it can play in helping us understand environmental problems and identifying potential solutions. However, there were a number of things that were frustrating in the class. Many of the lectures felt extremely abstract and high-level, so at times it was difficult to really grasp what the point of the lecture was and to understand the examples. I also felt that the assignments were not a great reflection of the concepts in class and, for the most part, did not feel demanding enough for a graduate-level course. I think if the assignments involved more examples and asked us to explore the issues in more detail, it would have helped us better understand the concepts. The coffee LCA assignment was a good assignment, but I was surprised that several of the others were so minimal because they didn't seem to provide much reinforcement of the class concepts. The group project that I was involved also seemed not as thoroughly conceived as it could have been. The organization we worked with did not seem like they had a good idea of what they wanted us to do and did not end up providing much information. We were forced to take the project in a different and ultimately less interesting direction than the initial project scope had been outlined. In terms of the debates, I thought the topics were all interesting, but the structure of the debates made them almost always devolve into an argument that more often than not was uncomfortable to watch and participate it (especially during the Q&A section). I wonder if there's a better way to structure them to make them more organized, productive and genial?

The course effectively provides a broad overview of many topics in industrial ecology. There were many guest lecturers, which added variety to the class and invited in more perspectives. Additionally, there were in-class debates about different policy issues that relate to industrial ecology, which were informative as well. The main area where the course could be improved was in the group project component, which took up about half of the class time. First of all, the projects could have been introduced earlier in the course to allow for more time. Second, each project should have been vetted to identify whether or not the client would be able to provide adequate data to allow students to actually apply industrial ecology tools, rather than have to make broad estimations and remain in the theoretical realm.

S: Guest speakers. All the guests were amazing and super interesting
W:  the topics were covered very superficially and was hard to digest the concepts.

I though that it was a good overview of the field which appeals to a wide audience. For those of us with a background in the sciences, it did not fell thorough and did not give a firm understanding of technique and method around some of the analytical tools such as material flow analysis.

Weakness: The homework was simultaneously not challenging (MFAs) or not reflective of anything learned in class (critical reading review and debates). The only homework that was appropriate was the LCA assessment which took time, but required the students to read the document. The final project had little guidance on how to work as a team and what the expected deliverables were. The companies were poorly vetted for their ability to provide useful data - so the expectation on both the corporate and student end seemed mismatched. I try to gage the expected level of output by the instructions given, previous grading rigor and the time given to perform the assignment. The time given to this assignment was very long, but lacked everything else which would have indicated that they expected any original work. 

Who came up with the debates? Why were we graded on presentation skills when they weren't taught in class. While a noble cause, why is memorizing a dynamic speech important for industrial ecology? 

Why did we have to do a critical reading review? What was the point of that and how does it relate to industrial ecology? No mention of this and we had to do it really early on in the course when we hadn't really read too much about the topic to develop our own opinions on the topic.

Final Project: This was embarrassing to do with my team. We were not prepared to deal with a client and manage expectations. After the poor engagement with the class my teammates were brainwashed into thinking there were like zero expectations for them for the project. I hope they are right given the produce we had to collectively turn in. I'm blaming this on the class rather than my teammates because I don't want to think that FES accepted a bunch of academic loafs and regurgitates. I think this is what this class does to people. The expectations all over this class were completely mismatched.

the Class was interesting but if the department wants to retain students it should make the intro class a bit more engaging, lectures less randomized and introduce the group project earlier in the semester.

Strengths are lots of good lecturers, some of whom are the pioneers in the field. Biggest weakness was that there was no clear head of the class. I imagine Marion was this last year, and organization of the class suffered this year from a lack of clear leadership.

The greatest strength of this class is it offers an opportunity for students to work with an actual client and help them to deal with industrial waste problems. Although it was very time-consuming and stressful, the whole process was very rewarding and I truly learned a lot from it. A weakness of this class is that the lecture is slightly too theoretical that we did not know how to actually incorporate the knowledge in class into our projects.

The most beneficial aspect of the class was the final project, which allowed us to work in teams on practical application of industrial ecology concepts to a real-world situation. However, apart from this, the class consisted of dry lectures and little discussion of required readings or practical applications of industrial ecology concepts. It could be massively improved by inviting more outside speakers to introduce how they handle industrial ecology-related challenges in their careers, and by changing the teaching style to force students into active learning -- e.g. small group discussions, class discussions, interactive modules, etc.
talk to faculty before deciding the project preferences
I would not advice them to take the course.
I would recommend jumping ahead to the Advanced Industrial Ecology course. This class was very basic and did not cover issues in depth.
This is an overview class. As such, the range of learning outcomes may be outside your control.

You will find this course worthwhile if you'd like to learn about how industrial ecology as a field of research works, and if you are looking to identify what part of that field you'd like to pursue further in your academic career.
Is a class that gives an overview of I.E. If a student has already background in such topics, the class might not be very challenging.
Skip this class and take one of the more advanced classes in the field. Life cycle assessment looks to be a far more useful class.
Unfortunately, nothing was taught here that you couldn't learn from reading a few blog posts about the topic. There was little depth to the subject matter (it was a survey course though...)
It's a good starting point, but don't expect too much of industrial ecology right off the bat. You kinda have to make your own way.

The final project is very time-consuming so you should definitely start working on it as early as possible. Also, treat this project as a great learning opportunity because I truly learned a lot from it. Otherwise, the whole process can be very painful if you just treat it as a job.
Unless the teaching style is changed to be more interactive, I recommend waiting until a different professor team teaches the course before taking it.
